<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>

<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_digest_auth_get_username:
```c
_MHD_EXTERN char *
MHD_digest_auth_get_username (struct MHD_Connection *connection)
{
  const struct MHD_RqDAuth *params;
  char *username;
  size_t buf_size;
  enum MHD_DigestAuthUsernameType uname_type;

  params = MHD_get_rq_dauth_params_ (connection);
  if (NULL == params)
    return NULL;

  uname_type = get_rq_uname_type (params);

  if ( (MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_UNAME_TYPE_STANDARD != uname_type) &&
       (MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_UNAME_TYPE_EXTENDED != uname_type) )
    return NULL;

  buf_size = get_rq_unames_size (params, uname_type);

  mhd_assert (0 != buf_size);

  username = (char *) MHD_calloc_ (1, buf_size);
  if (NULL == username)
    return NULL;

  if (1)
  {
    struct MHD_DigestAuthUsernameInfo uname_strct;
    size_t used;

    memset (&uname_strct, 0, sizeof(uname_strct));

    used = get_rq_uname (params, uname_type, &uname_strct,
                         (uint8_t *) username, buf_size);
    if (uname_type != uname_strct.uname_type)
    { /* Broken encoding for extended notation */
      free (username);
      return NULL;
    }
    (void) used; /* Mute compiler warning for non-debug builds */
    mhd_assert (buf_size >= used);
  }

  return username;
}
```

explanation: Only operations that can affect or rely on buffer bounds and usage by string.h functions need investigation for MISRA C Rule 21.17. The code contains a single direct string.h function call (memset) and several related buffer-size/usage operations (computing buf_size, allocating username, passing username and buf_size to get_rq_uname, and the subsequent assertion). These fragments must be checked together to ensure no access beyond the allocated username buffer (e.g. whether get_rq_unames_size returns a correct size including any required terminator, whether get_rq_uname respects the provided buf_size when writing, and whether the post-call check prevents out-of-bounds access). Other lines (parameter retrieval, enum checks, NULL checks, free(username), (void) used, returns, simple assignments) do not call string.h functions nor manipulate buffers in a way that could lead to accesses beyond object bounds, so they do not need investigation for this rule.
